moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3
comment:
McDonnell's invention. Usual here is 5. 0-0,
the Muzio Gambit,
 which sacrifices a piece for a fierce attack on
black's undeveloped kingside. 5. Ne5 the Salvio
Gambit was also played in the nineteenth century. 
Eventually it was found that 5. Qh4+ 6. Kf1  Nc6 $1
refutes it, as complex analysis would show.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O
comment:
6. Qxf3, as also played by McDonnell, would
lead to more independent positions.  Note it is as if
White played a Muzio and followed it up with Nc3
instead of the usual Qxf3

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6
comment:
Black plans to
place his Queen on Qf6, so that after White plays Qxf3
he cannot at once follow this with Qxf4 because Black
will exchange queens. With the text move Black keeps
White's knight out of Nd5 where he may eventually
harass Black's Queen. However,  if 6..
Qf3, Nd5?? then 7..Qd4+ and Qxc4 but in this wild 
open position there is not time for such a move.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6 7. Qxf3 Qf6 8. e5
comment:
Itâs quite worth another pawn to open the
position further

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6 7. Qxf3 Qf6 8. e5 Qxe5 9. Bxf7+
1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6 7. Qxf3 Qf6 8. e5 Qxe5 9. Bxf7+ Kxf7 10. d4 Qxd4+
1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6 7. Qxf3 Qf6 8. e5 Qxe5 9. Bxf7+ Kxf7 10. d4 Qxd4+ 11. Be3
comment:
The piquant point, Black can not play
11...Qxe3+? because after QxQ Blackâs Bishop Pawn is pinned and cannot recapture. Notice how all of Whiteâs moves gain time and development.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6 7. Qxf3 Qf6 8. e5 Qxe5 9. Bxf7+ Kxf7 10. d4 Qxd4+ 11. Be3 Qg7 12. Bxf4
comment:
Black has two extra pieces, but he is far
behind in developement and his King is 
 very exposed

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6 7. Qxf3 Qf6 8. e5 Qxe5 9. Bxf7+ Kxf7 10. d4 Qxd4+ 11. Be3 Qg7 12. Bxf4 Nf6 13. Ne4
comment:
White must strike while the iron is hot. The
text starts on attack against Blackâs
 knight, which covers his King. Black cannot play
13...Nxe4 because 14. Be5 or Bh6
 dis. + wins the Queen.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6 7. Qxf3 Qf6 8. e5 Qxe5 9. Bxf7+ Kxf7 10. d4 Qxd4+ 11. Be3 Qg7 12. Bxf4 Nf6 13. Ne4 Be7 14. Bg5
comment: Continuing the pressure against the Knight.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6 7. Qxf3 Qf6 8. e5 Qxe5 9. Bxf7+ Kxf7 10. d4 Qxd4+ 11. Be3 Qg7 12. Bxf4 Nf6 13. Ne4 Be7 14. Bg5 Rg8
comment:
inderectly menacing 
 Whiteâs King Knight Pawn

1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4 5. Nc3 gxf3 6. O-O c6 7. Qxf3 Qf6 8. e5 Qxe5 9. Bxf7+ Kxf7 10. d4 Qxd4+ 11. Be3 Qg7 12. Bxf4 Nf6 13. Ne4 Be7 14. Bg5 Rg8 15. Qh5+ Qg6 16. Nd6+
comment:
If now 16..Bxd6 17. Rxf6+ followed by 18.
 Rxg6  notice that Black's Queen is 
 pinned, so he cannot play 17...Qxf6
